Description: Therapeutic cancer vaccines are designed to prime and boost the immune system to detect and destroy antigen-expressing tumor cells.  The scope of cancer vaccines is defined by the vaccine platform, the nature and quality of cancer antigens that are incorporated and ultimately the tumor microenvironment.  The antigen repertoire that can be incorporated into vaccines is broad and includes self antigens, individualized neoantigens and viral antigens. In this session, the speakers will discuss approaches to improve vaccine antigen selection, immunogenicity and identify determinants of efficacy. Additionally, they will assess the mode of action of various cancer vaccine platforms, discuss differences between spontaneous and vaccine-triggered T-cell responses in cancer immunotherapy and propose combinatorial approaches to enhance cancer vaccines to provide therapeutic benefit.
SearchResultBody: SY18. Cancer Vaccines: New Developments and Clinical Response
Title: Cancer Vaccines: New Developments and Clinical Response
